item.title: Scott add a quote by Neal Stephenson
item.description: "Arguing with anonymous strangers on the Internet is a sucker's game because they almost always turn out to be&mdash;or to be indistinguishable from&mdash;self-righteous sixteen-year-olds possessing infinite amounts of free time." -- Neal Stephenson

item.title: Scott add a quote by Neal Stephenson
item.description: "Until a man is twenty-five, he still thinks, every so often, that under the right circumstances he could be the baddest motherfucker in the world. If I moved to a martial-arts monastery in China and studied real hard for ten years. If my family was wiped out by Colombian drug dealers and I swore myself to revenge. If I got a fatal disease, had one year to live, and devoted it to wiping out street crime. If I just dropped out and devoted my life to being bad." -- Neal Stephenson

item.title: Scott add a quote by Neal Stephenson
item.description: "Whenever serious and competent people need to get things done in the real world, all considerations of tradition and protocol fly out the window." -- Neal Stephenson

item.title: Scott add a quote by Richard Yates
item.description: "if you wanted to do something absolutely honest, something true, it always turned out to be a thing that had to be done alone." -- Richard Yates

item.title: Scott add a quote by Paul Bowles
item.description: "Death is always on the way, but the fact that you don't know when it will arrive seems to take away from the finiteness of life. It's that terrible precision that we hate so much. But because we don't know, we get to think of life as an inexhaustible well. Yet everything happens a certain number of times, and a very small number, really. How many more times will you remember a certain afternoon of your childhood, some afternoon that's so deeply a part of your being that you can't even conceive of your life without it? Perhaps four or five times more. Perhaps not even. How many more times will you watch the full moon rise? Perhaps twenty. And yet it all seems limitless." -- Paul Bowles
